turntable.content: Anthracite, a metamorphic rock, is a hard, compact form of coal. Anthracite has the highest carbon count of all of the different types of coal.

location.content: Anthracite can be found in northeastern Pennsylvania, Colorado, Canada, and Peru.

usage.content: Anthracite is commonly used as a domestic fuel in hand-fired stoves or in automatic stoker furnaces. Smaller pieces of anthracite are used in filters and as an ingredient in charcoal.

facts.content: Anthracite burns with a short, blue, and smokeless flame.

turntable.content:
The mineral augite is found in many types of igneous rocks. Although it may be interesting to geologists, augite does not have many uses.

The chemical formula for augite is (Ca,Mg,Fe,Na)(Mg,Fe,Al)(Si,Al) 2O6

location.content: Augite can be found in New York, Oregon, and Colorado, as well as in Germany, Italy, and France.

usage.content: There are no significant commercial uses of augite.

facts.content: Augite is only of interest to mineral collectors. It has no known uses.

turntable.content: Basalt, an igneous rock, forms when hot lava rapidly cools on Earth’s surface. Basalt is one of the most common rocks found in Earth’s crust.

location.content: Basalt can be found in various areas throughout the world that have or once had volcanic activity, including South Africa, Iceland, Italy, Russia, Brazil, and Canada. In the United States, basalt can be found in Washington, Oregon, California, and Hawaii.

usage.content: Basalt is commonly used to create floor tiles and as an aggregate in roads and asphalt.

facts.content: Basalt is also a common rock on the surface of the moon and on Mars.

turntable.content: Bauxite, a sedimentary rock, is the main ore of aluminum. A mixture of different minerals, bauxite is the primary source for metallic aluminum.

location.content: Bauxite can be found in Australia, China, Brazil, and India.

usage.content: Bauxite is commonly used in the manufacturing of aluminum cans, airplanes, sporting equipment, and electronic equipment.

facts.content: Bauxite is strip mined because it is found near Earth’s surface.

turntable.content: Bituminous coal, a sedimentary rock, is a soft form of coal that is of poorer quality than anthracite. Bituminous coal is the most common coal used around the world.

location.content: Bituminous coal can be found in the Appalachian region of the United States, and in Russia and Australia.

usage.content: Bituminous coal is used in the process of steel making and power generation.

facts.content: Bituminous coal must be coked before it is used for industrial processes. Coking is the process by which volatile components are removed from the coal.

turntable.content:
The mineral calcite is one of the most common minerals on Earth. Calcite is the primary mineral component of stalactites and stalagmites, which are often found in caves.

The chemical formula for calcite is CaCO 3.

location.content: Calcite can be found in Ohio, Illinois, Tennessee, New Jersey, Wisconsin, Kansas, and Oklahoma, as well as in Germany, Brazil, Mexico, England, India, and Iceland.

usage.content: Calcite is commonly used for making glass, paper, photographs, statues, building materials, pigments, pharmaceuticals, and animal food. Calcite neutralizes acids, so it can be crushed and spread onto fields as a soil conditioner.

facts.content: High-purity calcite is made into antacid tablets.

turntable.content: Conglomerate, a sedimentary rock, is composed of many different rock and mineral fragments that are cemented together. Conglomerates are large-grained, which means they usually have interesting textures.

location.content: Conglomerate can be found in Colorado as well as in Australia, Ireland, and Spain.

usage.content: Conglomerate is commonly used as ornamental rock for buildings, monuments, gravestones, and tiles.

facts.content: The different particles in conglomerates are cemented together by various minerals.

turntable.content:
The mineral fluorite is well-known for its variety of colors and unique properties related to light. Fluorite is often referred to as “the most colorful mineral in the world.”

The chemical formula for fluorite is CaF 2.

location.content: Fluorite can be found in Tennessee, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, and Colorado, as well as in England, Spain, China, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, and Germany.

usage.content: Fluorite is commonly used to make pottery, ceramics, and plastics. It is also used to produce hydrofluoric acid, and it is the source of fluoride in toothpaste.

facts.content: Fluorite is often fluorescent, which means that it will glow under ultraviolet (UV) light.

turntable.content: Gneiss, a metamorphic rock, often displays prominent banding patterns. Gneiss’ composition and texture resembles another metamorphic rock, schist.

location.content: Gneiss can be found throughout the world; in the United States, it can be found in mountain ranges such as the Adirondacks and the Rocky Mountains.

usage.content: Gneiss is commonly used in buildings, roads, and curbs. It can also be used to create paper weights, statues, bookends, bowls, etc.

facts.content: Gneiss makes up the largest part of Earth’s lower crust; gneiss could be found under all of the continents within the crust.

turntable.content: Granite, an igneous rock, forms from molten rock called magma. Granite is often the rock layer upon which sedimentary and continental rocks rest.

location.content: Granite can be found throughout the world; in the United States, granite can be found in New Hampshire, Vermont, North Carolina, and Georgia.

usage.content: Granite is commonly used as a building stone; when polished, granite is used to make monuments, statues, gravestones, and countertops.

facts.content: Granite was used with limestone as a building material for the Egyptian pyramids.

turntable.content:
The mineral graphite is the crystal form of carbon.

Graphite is difficult to ignite, which is why it is rarely used for heating purposes.

The chemical formula for graphite is C.

location.content: Graphite can be found in New York and Texas, as well as in Russia, Mexico, Greenland, and India.

usage.content: Graphite is commonly used in the production of “lead” in pencils. It is also used as a dry lubricant and steel hardener.

facts.content: Graphite is used to make golf clubs because it is a flexible and light material.

turntable.content:
The mineral gypsum is commonly found in sedimentary environments that have usually been exposed to extremely salty water.

The chemical formula for gypsum is CaSO4 • 2H2O.

location.content: Gypsum can be found in Utah and Colorado, as well as in Mexico and Italy.

usage.content: Gypsum is commonly used in industrial or building plaster, cement manufacture, and for agriculture. It is also used to make a variety of dental products.

facts.content: Gypsum crystals are among the largest on the entire planet. Gypsum crystals can be colorless and transparent.

turntable.content:
The mineral halite can be easily distinguished by its salty taste. Halite can be found in ancient bedrock all over the world where large seas and salt lakes once existed.

dThe chemical formula for halite is NaCl.

location.content: Halite can be found in California and Utah, as well as in Germany and France.

usage.content: Halite is commonly used in food seasoning and food preservation. It is also used to make sodium hydroxide, soda ash, caustic soda, hydrochloric acid, chlorine, ceramic glazes, mineral waters, soap, water softeners, de-icing agents, and in photography. Single halite crystals can be used for ultraviolet and infrared transmission.

facts.content: Halite is commonly known as “rock salt.”

turntable.content: The mineral hematite is an important ore of iron. Crystals of hematite are considered very rare. The chemical formula for hematite is Fe 2O3.

location.content: Hematite can be found in England, Mexico, Brazil, Australia, and in the Lake Superior region of the United States.

usage.content: Hematite is commonly used in the manufacture of steel, iron nails, appliances, furniture, tools, bridges, buildings, cars, trains, and railroads.

facts.content: Hematite is sometimes used in jewelry, either as black reflective stones or as a piece of jewelry itself.

turntable.content: Limestone, a sedimentary rock, is composed of the mineral calcite, which comes from the remains of marine organisms. Marine debris accumulates over time and forms beds of limestone.

location.content: Limestone can be found in Michigan, Florida, and in the Niagara region of the United States, as well as in Ireland, France, England, Sweden, and Belgium.

usage.content:
Limestone is commonly used in the construction of buildings and as a component of cement and glass.

When limestone is crushed into a powder form, it can be used as a soil conditioner to neutralize acidic soils.

facts.content: Limestone is often the best rock for finding fossils; sometimes a limestone sample can be composed entirely of fossils.

turntable.content:
The mineral magnetite is the most magnetic mineral on Earth, and it is a valuable source of iron ore. Small grains of magnetite occur in almost all igneous and metamorphic rocks.

The chemical formula for magnetite is Fe 3O4.

location.content: Magnetite can be found in South Africa, Germany, Russia, and in some areas of the United States.

usage.content: Magnetite is commonly used to make steel, iron nails, appliances, furniture, tools, bridges, buildings, cars, trains, and railroads.

facts.content: Magnetite is a natural magnet, which is why the word “magnet” is in its name.

turntable.content: The mineral malachite is a very popular semi-precious, green stone. Tumbled stones, beads, and carvings of malachite are very popular throughout the world. The chemical formula for malachite is Cu 2Co3(OH) 2.

location.content: Malachite can be found in Mexico, Australia, England, Russia, and in several areas of the southwestern United States.

usage.content: Malachite is commonly used to create beads, jewelry, carved figurines, and vases.

facts.content: Malachite has a banded light and dark green design, which makes it unlike any other semi-precious stone.

turntable.content: Marble, a metamorphic rock, forms when limestone is heated. Marble preserves the different layers of limestone; however, fossils in limestone are destroyed during metamorphism.

location.content: Marble can be found in Vermont, Maryland, Tennessee, and Massachusetts, as well as in Canada, Italy, Germany, and Spain.

usage.content: Marble is commonly used in construction and for making decorative household items such as tile, countertops, statues, etc.

facts.content: The Leaning Tower of Pisa in Pisa, Italy is made of white and pastel marble.

turntable.content:
The mineral microcline is a type of feldspar that is not very well-known.

The chemical formula for microcline is KAlSi3O8.

location.content: Microcline can be found in Colorado and North Carolina, as well as in Russia, Norway, and Madagascar.

usage.content: Microcline samples can be clear, white, pale-yellow, brick-red, or green. Green microline is commonly used as a semi-precious stone under the name of Amazonite.

facts.content: Microcline is actually a combination of other minerals that share the same chemistry but have different crystal structures.

turntable.content:
The mineral muscovite is a type of mica that can be found in igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks. Muscovite forms durable sheets that are commercially valuable.

The chemical formula for muscovite is KAl 2(AlSi3O10)(OH) 2.

location.content: Muscovite can be found in India, Pakistan, Brazil, and in some areas of the United States.

usage.content: Muscovite is commonly used to manufacture electronic insulators, and it is used in paints, as joint cement, as a dusting agent, and in plastics, roofing, rubber, and welding rods.

facts.content: Sheets of muscovite have high heat and electrical insulating properties.

turntable.content: Obsidian, an igneous rock, forms when volcanic lava cools too quickly to allow crystals to form. Obsidian is glass-like and can be very sharp.

location.content: Obsidian can be found in California, Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, Texas, Washington, Oregon, Virginia, and Idaho, as well as in Canada, Chile, Greece, Italy, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Scotland, and Argentina.

usage.content: Obsidian is commonly used as a gemstone and to make surgical scalpel blades. In ancient times, obsidian was primarily used to produce sharp blades or arrowheads. It was also polished to create early mirrors.

facts.content: Obsidian has been used in various surgeries because obsidian blades have an edge that is many times sharper than steel blades.

turntable.content: Pumice, an igneous rock, forms from lava that is rich in gases. Pumice is very porous, meaning it has a lot of little holes in it from those gas bubbles.

location.content: Pumice can be found in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Oregon, as well as in Italy, Greece, Chile, Spain, and Turkey.

usage.content:
Pumice is commonly used to make lightweight concrete and as an additive for cement.

Because of its abrasive nature, pumice is also used in polishes, pencil erasers, and cosmetic exfoliants; pumice stones are used to exfoliate dead skin.

Pumice can be ground into a fine powder and added to cleaners and toothpastes.

facts.content: Pumice stones are used to remove dead skin during spa treatments.

turntable.content:
The mineral quartz is found in nearly every environment and in almost every rock type on Earth.

Quartz comes in a variety of colors and forms and is a popular gemstone.

The chemical formula for quartz is SiO2.

location.content: Quartz can be found throughout the world; it is abundant on Earth’s surface.

usage.content: Quartz is commonly used to manufacture glass, paints, abrasives, and precision instruments. It is also a popular semi-precious gemstone used in jewelry.

facts.content: Quartz is the most common mineral on the face of the Earth.

turntable.content: Shale, a sedimentary rock, is composed of silt, clay, or mud that has been pressed together into layers. Shale sometimes breaks along these layers.

location.content: Shale can be found throughout the world. In the United States, shale can be found in Colorado, Wyoming, and Utah.

usage.content: Shale is commonly used in cement, bricks, concrete, for road construction, and to create ceramic products.

facts.content: Shale often preserves fossils and fossilized animal tracks.

turntable.content: Slate, a metamorphic rock, has a very fine grain. Slate can often be split into parallel layers.

location.content: Slate can be found in Pennsylvania, Vermont, New York, and Maine, as well as in Newfoundland, Brazil, England, France, Belgium, and Germany.

usage.content: Slate is commonly used in roofing and floor tiles, and it is also used as the flat beds of billiard tables. If crushed, slate can be used in paint.

facts.content: Slate was used to create school blackboards.
